No Additional Materials are required. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 385, 400]]<|/det|> ## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 411, 718, 482]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use a pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 494, 253, 509]]<|/det|> Answer all questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 520, 758, 551]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 816, 107]]<|/det|>
The IGCSE class is carrying out refraction experiments using a rectangular glass block optical pins.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 120, 146, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 880, 152]]<|/det|>
In the middle of the space below, draw a line, \(10\mathrm{cm}\) long, across the page and label it \(\mathbf{AB}\) . This line represents one side of the glass block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 780, 875, 798]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 810, 148, 827]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 810, 534, 827]]<|/det|>
Draw a normal to this line at the centre of AB.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 810, 875, 827]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 840, 146, 858]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 840, 875, 872]]<|/det|>
Draw a line at \(30^{\circ}\) to the normal to represent an incident ray. This line should be at least \(6\mathrm{cm}\) long. Label this line \(\mathbf{EF}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 855, 875, 873]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 886, 148, 904]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 886, 875, 933]]<|/det|>
Mark the positions of two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line \(\mathbf{EF}\). They should be positioned at suitable places on the line in order carry out a ray-tracing experiment as accurately as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 918, 876, 935]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 823, 122]]<|/det|>
A student finds that his completed results from the refraction experiment do not match the theory. The student carried out the experiment correctly and with reasonable care.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 873, 168]]<|/det|>
Suggest a practical reason why the results could differ slightly from the results expected from the theory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[798, 274, 875, 292]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 5]

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 608, 92]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 104, 408, 122]]<|/det|>

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 585, 737, 603]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 616, 875, 634]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\) ............................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 647, 148, 666]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 647, 875, 680]]<|/det|>
A student pours \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into a beaker. She records the temperature \(\theta_0\) of the water.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 680, 870, 700]]<|/det|>
\[\theta_{0} = \text{................................................................} 86^{\circ}\text{C}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 712, 843, 730]]<|/det|>
She starts a stopclock and records the temperature \(\theta_{1}\) of the water at time \(t = 100 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 743, 870, 763]]<|/det|>
\[\theta_{1} = \text{................................................................} 72^{\circ}\text{C}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 780, 180, 798]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 780, 875, 813]]<|/det|>
Calculate the temperature difference \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\) between \(\theta_0\) and room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}} = (\theta_0 - \theta_{\mathrm{R}})\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 826, 870, 844]]<|/det|>
\[\theta_{\mathrm{A}} = \text{................................................................} ....................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 863, 183, 882]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 863, 873, 881]]<|/det|>
Calculate the temperature fall \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) of the hot water using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}} = (\theta_0 - \theta_1)\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 906, 870, 925]]<|/det|>
\[\theta_{\mathrm{H}} = \text{................................................................} ....................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 816, 107]]<|/det|>
The student empties the beaker. She pours \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water to the beaker, and stirs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 575, 138]]<|/det|>
She records the temperature \(\theta_{2}\) of the warm water.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 151, 828, 173]]<|/det|>
\[\theta_{2} = \text{........................................} 59^{\circ}\text{C}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 185, 858, 203]]<|/det|>
She starts the stopclock and records the temperature \(\theta_{3}\) of the water at time \(t = 100 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 216, 828, 238]]<|/det|>
\[\theta_{3} = \text{........................................} 44^{\circ}\text{C}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 252, 180, 271]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 252, 873, 286]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 299, 828, 317]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 330, 180, 348]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 330, 873, 365]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[542, 377, 828, 395]]<|/det|>
\[\theta_{\mathrm{W}} = \text{........................................} ....................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 392, 875, 411]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 424, 873, 490]]<|/det|>
The student suggests that the rate of temperature change is proportional to the difference between the starting temperature and room temperature. This can be expressed as \(\frac{\theta_{\mathrm{A}}}{\theta_{\mathrm{H}}} = \frac{\theta_{\mathrm{B}}}{\theta_{\mathrm{W}}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 494, 873, 528]]<|/det|>
